qas.question: When did Tucson begin offering city council candidates public funding?
What is the spending limit for Tucson city council candidates to get public funding?
What is the spending limit for Tucson mayoral candidates to get public funding?
What major cities later adopted Tucson's city council public funding system?

answers.text: San Francisco and New York City

qas.question: How many $10+ donations must Tucson city council candidates receive to get public funding?

context: Tucson is known for being a trailblazer in voluntary partial publicly financed campaigns. Since <a0_0>1985<a0_0/>, both mayoral and council candidates have been eligible to receive matching public funds from the city. To become eligible, council candidates must receive <a4_0>200<a4_0/> donations of $10 or more (300 for a mayoral candidate). Candidates must then agree to spending limits equal to <a1_0>33¢ for every registered Tucson voter<a1_0/>, or $79,222 in 2005 (the corresponding figures for mayor are <a2_0>64¢ per registered voter<a2_0/>, or $142,271 in 2003). In return, candidates receive matching funds from the city at a 1:1 ratio of public money to private donations. The only other limitation is that candidates may not exceed 75% of the limit by the date of the primary. Many cities, such as <a3_0>San Francisco and New York City<a3_0/>, have copied this system, albeit with more complex spending and matching formulas.
